captions.text:
Light is a wave, and as it travels it does
its "waving" along a certain direction - its

polarization. Polarization, among other things,
heavily influences the way light bounces and

scatters - that's why horizontally polarized
light reflects off of a lake or car windshield,

which in turn is why sunglasses with a vertical
polarizing filter can block that light.

And in the hot plasma of the baby universe,
light was bouncing off of electrons left and

right - until the plasma cooled enough to
become transparent so the light could start

traveling through space. But before heading
out on its 13+ billion year journey, this

light bounced one last time off of the plasma,
and the direction each photon went was influenced

by how its polarization interacted with the
precise temperature, density and motion of
the plasma.

So if we measure the polarization of light
coming from this cosmic background radiation,

it can tell us about the big bang. The details
are complicated, but roughly speaking, clumps

in the plasma of the early universe created
polarization aligned along or across the direction

from hot to cold, while jiggles created polarization
at 45° angles to the hot-cold direction.

And by jiggles I mean the stretching and squeezing
of space due to gravitational waves passing
through.

Anyway, starting with the results from the
BICEP telescope at the South Pole, we see

that while a majority of the polarization
came from clumps in the early universe, about
15% of it seems to come from jiggles.

And these jiggles are a big deal - they were
caused just fractions of fractions of a second

into the life of the universe by quantum fluctuations
of the gravitational field, so not only does

their discovery mark the first confirmation
that gravity is indeed a quantum mechanical

phenomenon, but it also opens the door for
us to look 380,000 years farther back than
ever before, into the very birth of our cosmos.

Congrats to the BICEP collaboration! - assuming
of course, that their results are confirmed
by other experiments.

title: A Polarizing Discovery About the Big Bang!

the big bang happened everywhere. the CMB is but the limit of how far (and 
old) we can see into the universe.
at every second it passes, the CMB grows ~300Mm in radius, if that makes 
any sense.
its not like the universe is finite, its just that the light from the big 
bang which is further away than the CMB didn't have enough time to reach us 
yet.

comments.text:
For those who just watched the video, I would like to add that 3 papers 
were recently published:
http://arxiv.org/pdf/1405.5857v1.pdf
 http://arxiv.org/pdf/1405.7351v1.pdf
 http://arxiv.org/pdf/1403.5166v2.pdf
...which doubt the validity of the experiment. The original authors have 
also released an updated version of the results, admitting that they may 
actually be the result of Milky Way dust interference.

I'm not saying the results are necessarily wrong. However, we should be 
more cautious in the future.﻿

comments.author: Omar Yassin

comments.text:
+BattousaiHBr Yeah, entropy is better described as a count of degrees of 
freedom of a system or how much energy is available. Talking about 
order/disorder or chaos can be a bit deceptive, an increasingly chaotic 
system requires an increase of entropy to describe it (coarse graining).

So if heat death occurs it is better described as the universe reaching 
thermal equilibrium at maximum entropy, ie no more energy is available to 
do work on a microscopic level. It is still chaotic in a mathematical 
sense, even if everything is at absolute zero and no chemical processes are 
possible.

comments.text:
The universe started in a state of almost complete order, low entropy. The 
universe everywhere started in a dense hot state which was almost exactly 
the same temperature and density everywhere, with only about 1 part in 
100,000th difference anywhere (proven by WMAP and Planck telescope data). 
Entropy increase causes a system of order to evolve into a system of 
disorder. Gravitational collapse increased entropy, but things like 
chemistry and biology decrease entropy.

comments.text:
I never made the assertion one way or the other about the BICEP results. 
I'm just pointing out the contradiction between your assertion that the 
article in question was "shown to be false" while the article in question 
proposed an alternative explanation, without going so far as to prove why 
it was the ONLY valid hypothesis for the observations (and thus disproving 
the claim in question.) There's a difference between proving that something 
might not be the cause and proving that something can not be the cause. 
Even if BICEP is wrong, that doesn't automatically prove any other 
hypothesis right, at least not by itself, with no further evidence or 
observations.

comments.text:
A photon is an elementary particle, the quantum of light and all other 
forms of electromagnetic radiation, and the force carrier for the 
electromagnetic force, even when static via virtual photons.

Said simply, the only way particles can interact is with electromagnetism 
and light "photons" is the way this happens.

Effectively *all of chemistry* is simply complex ways particles use light 
to interact.

comments.author: Sgt Moose

comments.text:
The fallacy here is that you think the big bang theory tells us anything 
about the moment of the big bang, or any time "before" it.

In addition, conservation of energy doesn't apply to the universe. 
Conservation laws arise because of Noether's theorem, which states that 
specific quantities are conserved when there is invariance for specific 
variables. For example, translational invariance - the fact that physical 
systems shouldn't change when we shift the system elsewhere in the universe 
- leads to conservation of momentum. Time variance gives rise to 
conservation of energy, but the universe isn't time-invariant - metric 
expansion occurs, so a physical system today at the cosmic scale would be 
much different from a physical system tomorrow. Therefore energy is not 
conserved in the universe as a whole.

+ByRTD yO Peptides are literally just small proteins, there is no 
difference. Some classify them as separate (including wikipedia), others 
classify them as the same thing, because they are.
Even if we say they are separate, the point still stands that you CAN have 
a simple chain of as little as 10 aminos, and more complex versions are 
based on the first simple ones.

"They catalyze chemical reactions you idiot which are a type of 
information."
Fine, I'll concede that chemical reactions are technically information, but 
that kind of technical correctness is frowned upon because technically, 
literally everything that ever was, is, will be, happened, happens, and 
will happen is information. That definition of information envelops 
literally everything, and is therefore useless.
Regardless, catalyzing enzymes don't extract information from DNA (or RNA). 
A catalyst is anything that speeds up a chemical reaction, NOT something 
that starts a reaction that otherwise wouldn't have happened.

such as in mutations. Educate yourself"

LAUGHABLY WRONG. LOL. What an absolute nonsense you just wrote. First of

comments.author: ByRTD yO (byRTD)

comments.text:
+ByRTD yO
Before I adress any of that, your whole assumption is flawed. You say that 
via random chance, there are x possible states the universe could be in 
right now, and the odds of it being OUR state is lower than the total 
states, so it's impossible.
By the same logic, if a loterry has odds of 1 to a million, but only sells 
500 thousand tickets, it's impossible to win. This is obviously not true.

Also, you can't take a general possibility and cross it with a specific 
time in the middle like that.
Say you're in a crowd of 100 people hoping to win one of 10 new phones. 
There are of course 10 possible winners. Now, they're handing out one phone 
every 6 seconds, and it's been a minute. Right now, there are only six 
people who could have a new phone, but there are 10 phones to be had! The 
possible states are lower than the odds of it being the right state, but 
that doesn't mean it's impossible for you to have a phone, does it?
Your 2000 enzymes are the same situation. Only one out of every x possible 
state has all 2000, and as of now the universe has only been able to reach 
y states, and y is smaller than x. But the universe isn't over yet, 
eventually y=x. Just like eventually, they'll pass out all 10 phones. Right 
now, they've only handed out 6, but that doesn't mean it's impossible for 
you to have gotten one, and it doesn't mean it's impossible for the 
universe to have reached our state.

Now then, onto your pint.

Sorry, but "total number of atoms in the entire universe" isn't 
interchangeable with "weak ass guesstimate (based on things well known to 
be wildly inaccurate) number of atoms in the minute fraction of a fraction 
of a fraction of the actual universe that we can observe".
1: The entire universe is most likely infinite, and if it isn't we pretty 
much have no idea how big it is, how full of conventional matter it is, how 
spread out said matter is, how much of that matter is even in the form of 
matter, and what kind of atoms it is.
2: The observable universe is a glimpse into the past. At the closest point 
(Earth itself) it's 0 years old, at the furthest (an estimated 100 billion 
lightyears in every direction) it's about 14 billion years old. Simulating 
what that would all look like today is pretty much impossible, so we 
generally assume that it looks sort of like local space, and then calculate 
how many galaxies that would be, which gives us a number that could be 
orders of magnitude off because we have very little idea how matter density 
has evolved in the rest of the universe.
3a: Galaxies come in all sorts of sizes. If we're going by amount of stars, 
the biggest is IC 1011 with 100 trillion, I can't find THE smallest, but 
various sources say galaxies can have as few as 10 million. But most have 
200-400 billion, NOT 100 billion like you say, so if that's what we're 
basing things on, your number of atoms has to be multiplied by 2-4.
But estimating the number of stars per galaxy and then the number of atoms 
per star is needlessly complicated. We estimate the number of stars in a 
galaxy with the mass of the galaxy by the mass of an average star, and we 
estimate the number of atoms in a star with the mass of the star, the 
fraction of atoms in a star (it's not just hydrogen, the older a star gets 
the more different elements it contains) and their respective mass. So 
we're going from mass to number to mass again, and adding a bunch of 
averages and guesswork in the middle.
3b: And because we estimate the number of stars by mass, things get even 
less accurate. You can't just divide a galaxy by the mass of an average 
star and have the number of stars, because not every galaxy has the same 
star makeup. And no, no one type is common enough that we can just use that 
average.
Depending on age, makeup, density, brightness, etc. of a galaxy, we can 
estimate what types of stars a galaxy is made up of, and estimate their 
fractions. Each type of star has it's own average mass, but then each star 
changes size and brightness (but not mass) as it ages, further complicating 
things.
Which is why you really should go straight from "mass of average galaxy" to 
"atoms per galaxy", skipping stars entirely.
3c: Oh, and not all of a galaxies mass is stars. It was recently discovered 
that Andromeda, although only slightly larger and with slightly more stars 
than the Milky Way, is almost twice as massive, because of dark matter.
4: "A normal star is pretty much like our sun."
Oh god the ignorance. Even if that were true and everything I said about 
star types up there wrong, it still wouldn't help us. First, the type of 
star our sun belongs to is pretty big, it encompasses stars magnitudes 
larger than ours. Second, our sun doesn't have a set amount of atoms. As 
you may know, stars do this thing called fusion. That means a star that 
starts with only hydrogen will end with a whole bunch of heavier elements. 
And the heavier an element, the less atoms it has for the same mass. If the 
sun converted all its hydrogen to helium, it would have half as many atoms. 
But it doesn't just do that, it keeps fusing into heavier elements. 
Currently, the sun is 71% hydrogen, 27% helium, the rest is traces. Let's  
round that to 2/3 hydrogen, 1/3 helium. Helium has half as many atoms for 
the same mass of hydrogen, so by assuming the sun is 100% hydrogen, your 
atom count is off by 1/6.

Also, you're assuming there are only 10^101 "events" in the universe 
because (10^84) * (10^17)=10^101. That's great and all, but it just so 
happens that a second is not the smallest unit of time. Most stopwatches 
can tell you there are 10 milliseconds in 1 second. Many videogames run at 
60 frames per second. PC screens can refresh over 100 times per second. 
High speed cameras can record thousands of frames, and as I just found out 
they built one that records 4.4 trillion frames per second (jesus christ).
A yoctosecond is a septillionth of a second. It goes on and on, until we 
reach planck time. How long is that? Oh, just 5.4x10^-44 seconds.
18,518,519,000,000,000,000,704,192,456,256,424,240,232,224 per second. An 
18 with 42 0s. 18.5+10^42.

Let's fix your event equasion shall we?
Calculating the actual number of atoms in the universe would take too long 
and be too inaccurate, so we'll take time for now. Instead of 10^17 
seconds, we have 18.5+10^42 planck times. (10^84) * 
(18.5+10^42)=18.5+10^126.

Now lets look at those enzymes of yours.
"You calculate this by raising 20(amino acids available) to the power of 
2000(which are the 2000 different enzymes found in the simplest bacterium). 
So, 1/(10^20)^2000=1 in 10^40,000."

That assumes that
1: enzymes develop one at a time, isolated from each other, in totally 
different environments. Actually, their development is linked to each other 
(many enzymes are developments of a different enzyme, or are made possible 
by the existence of a previous enzyme).
2: that they all had to exist, just hanging out in a barren void, until the 
first bacterion somehow popped into being and collected all 2000. That's... 
not how it happened. Bacteria are thought to be the first lifeform, but not 
the first organism (for reference, a virus is an organism, but doesn't 
count as alive by standard definition). And it's a common known fact that 
bacteria evolved from simpler organisms, which in turn evolved from 
organicaly reproducing macromolecules, which in turn evolved from 
chemically reproducing molecules. It's a fluid process.
What we actually need to find out is the probability of the universe giving 
rise to conditions under which the basics can start (we don't actually need 
the conditions for the more complicated steps, because the simple steps 
MAKE those conditions). And those conditions are ridiculously easy. All you 
need is a floating object with a few basic molecules (the most complicated 
being water, wich is basically everywhere) that's occasionally not frozen 
solid. This can be caused by being close to a star (Earth, Mars), close to 
a massive planet that causes tidal heating (that frozen moon of Jupiter's 
that has a liquid ocean under the surface), a large amount of radiation...
So in this system alone, we have at least three places where it's possible, 
at least one of which actually did it (Earth), and one where we're getting 
more and more evidence that it almost did (Mars). In other systems, we're 
finding more exoplanets every day, many of which have been confirmed to 
have liquid water.
It also assumes that there can only be one winner, like it's a lottery (as 
in, there's only one "path" that leads to THE victory condition [you get 
all the money], and many paths that lead to THE loss condition [you get no 
money]). In reality, every single one of the trillions of planets and 
quadrillions of non-planetary bodies in every single galaxy have their OWN, 
chance, completely unrelated to the chances of the others. There are 
trillions and trillions of "paths" that lead to a victory condition 
(organic reproduction), and trillions and trillions of paths that lead to a 
loss condition (no reproduction).

Now let's look around. Huh, looks like the conditions are met in lots and 
lots of places, just like they should according to random chance (as long 
as one understands random chance, statistics, and what chance we're 
actually looking for).
comments.author: Behind TheWall

comments.text:
+Behind TheWall You're a special kind of retard aren't you? . How do I know 
there are about 10^80 atoms in the universe? Well,  our observable universe 
contains about 100 billion galaxies, which each has on average about a 
trillion stars. This gives us a total number of 10^23 stars. A normal star 
is pretty much like our Sun. The Sun contains a mass of 2×10^30 kg, which 
is gives us a total of 10^57 atoms of hydrogen per star. A total of 10^23 
stars containing 10^57 atoms both equate to 10^80 atoms. As for calculating 
the seconds, you just multiply 13.8 billion years by 365, then 24, then 60, 
then 60 again and you’ll have it which equals to about 10^17. Following so 
far? Good, because that is high school math for you.  Anyways, there aren’t 
enough atoms to produce the trial which is why the random chance argument 
holds no credibility.  Next.
comments.author: ByRTD yO (byRTD)

comments.text:
+mentalphysicalism I was responding to ByRTD's "I mean anything that goes 
beyond 10^80 since those are the total number of atoms in the entire 
universe."
I know constricting yourself to a finite part of the infinite universe is 
important so you can actually model something, but that's not what ByRTD 
was doing, he was saying that's the total number. Which is as wrong as 
saying the Milky Way only contains 50 stars.
.
1: The contents of the Big Bang are strewn out further than we can see. 
Currently the observable universe is 14 billion lightyears in every 
direction, but we know for a fact that there is matter beyond that, because 
it affects the matter we can see through gravity.
Likewise, the stars behind the galactic core are obscured, so we can only 
estimate how many there are based on gravitic effect, density projections, 
and average star size/mass.
2: The amount of atoms is not a constant, it's constantly changing. We 
split atoms In our atomic reactors. Suns fuse atoms in their cores. New 
subatomic particles are created by black holes and spontaneously in empty 
space.
Likewise, new stars are constantly being formed in the core and dying off 
everywhere (of course, this takes a while, so if we could count them it'd 
be accurate for a while).
comments.author: Behind TheWall

comments.text:
+Behind TheWall   I agree with the definition of the universe having 
multiple usages just like all words. The original definition was everything 
that exists but it has come to be used as the contents of the big bang 
because that is the known universe.  It is much easier to work with finite 
quantities and with what we can observe. Just as the Americas existed 
before Europeans discovered them there is no reason to assume that nothing 
exists beyond or before the limits of what we can presently detect. 
 Ancients thought all that existed was the 3 heavens in the dome of heaven. 
 We are stretching the limits of what we can detect and understand with 
present technology.

comments.author: TF8ase

comments.text:
I have a question. The earliest light which we can see is from 380,000 
years which is the CMB. Now we know there are jiggles in it, but it is 
possible that jiggles could have been created at anytime during this early 
380,000 year time span. How do we know that it was created during the first 
10^-43 secs after the Big Bang? We can prove gravity is a quantum 
mechanical phenomenon only if we are sure that the jiggles were present in 
the earliest stages of 10^-43s after the Big Bang when the universe was 
this tiny spec.﻿
comments.author: ashish sriram

comments.text:
God is having good laugh at our great human ingenuity. I think the problem 
with all this type of science is God created all of the things we will 
discover. Its like the game of monopoly; if you took out the rules the game 
would be pointless but, with the rules it is fun. However the game writer 
could have gone in many different directions with the game regardless of 
how the players feel. The writer or designer of the game decides what rules 
YOU get to play by. God designed the universe not with the rules we have to 
abide by. He designed it however he felt like it. Most likely in ways we 
will never understand. I just don't understand why anyone thinks the earth 
is that old. We are finding out more and more things change way quicker 
faster than anyone thought they did continually making the earth much 
younger all the time.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: N1shum

comments.text:
+Markee z Not quite. First, the orbital radius of the moon is currently 
increasing by about 3.8 centimeters per year...so if you divide the current 
orbital radius by that number you get a value a hell of a lot larger than 
20,000 years. Second, the Earth's core is cooling, yes, but not nearly 
enough to the point where it would be cold after a mere million years. The 
vast majority of the heat and energy from the Earth's core comes from 
radioactive decay of unstable elements like Uranium, and when Uranium 
decays via nuclear fission, it sets off even more nuclear reactions. So, 
really, the Earth is regaining about as much heat as it's losing, so 
estimates of how fast the Earth is cooling is maybe 100 degrees every 3 
billion years.
By the way, I just want to say I don't care whether or not you believe in a 
god; I care that you're spreading false information about our world just 
because it's consistent with whatever you believe in.
comments.author: Raymond Li

comments.text:

How about that little problem of the moon moving away from the earth at a 
rate that would put the moon in touch with the earth if you reversed time 
in only about 20,000 years. Or the other one little thing that the earth is 
hot and getting colder in the center. And if it was even close to a million 
years old it would be cold by now. Now count all your fingers and toes and 
multiply that by 100 and there would still be more reasons why the earth is 
no where near 1million years old.

comments.text:

I'm gonna play the Devils advocate here, but if we were to combine the 
total number of Christians, Muslims and Jews since they all technically 
believe in the same deity we get a number that is almost 4 billion.
4 billion people believing in one single deity for thousands of years at 
least gives that particular deity a higher percent chance of existing than 
the flying spaghetti monster.
Also, whether or not you believe in that God, he has had an irrefutable 
impact on the entire world, something which, again the flying spaghetti 
monster never has.
Think about it. If Jesus had never existed.. or the idea of him had never 
existed, the face of the world would probably be unrecognizable now.

comments.text:
As far as we can tell somewhere around 13.8 billion years. However I do 
understand that this number is up to change based on new data. But that's 
that the point of the scientific method. To always have doubt's and 
constantly question in order to arrive at a better understanding. If 
somebody has facts that would break this notion then collect the data, get 
it peer reviewed and collect your Nobel prize.
comments.author: James Rudy

comments.author: Fahid Hussain

comments.text:
+N1shum Science as far as we can tell, based on logical observation and 
deductive reasoning, points to a specific point which you are calling "the 
begging".  The nature of the "nothingness" to which you seem to need a god 
to provide an answer to will be closer understood through more 
investigation and understanding.   The big bang was not "the begging"  it 
is simply the closest thing we can perceive to a beginning with what we 
know.  Concluding to an inherit state of the universe before that would 
then be a jump in that logical discourse.  In other words, you would be 
making vast assumptions based on facts we do not understand/are currently 
ignorant of.  If you look at any avenue of science and jump to irrational 
conclusion of "we don't know, so it's obviously god" just makes god the 
void of ignorance that will further come to a rational light though 
generations of study.  All of the "grand" aspects of nature for example 
where all explained by a god or gods in the past.  Tides, sun, moon, 
celestial movement of stars in the sky etc.  But science gives us the 
answers to these seemingly unanswerable questions.  The origins of the 
universe, origins of consciousness in evolution and other "grand" 
unanswered questions are no different.
comments.author: James Rudy

comments.text:
Assuming God laughs, why would he laugh at us? We are his greatest 
creation, along with the universe and everything in it. If he created all 
of this stuff for us to discover, then isn't he vicariously enjoying every 
minute of our discovery? And if he created all of this stuff, why wouldn't 
it be completely consistent from one level to the next in all it's 
incredible complexity? Markee Z, you should try to see things on a greater 
scale than you are presently seeing them. And don't minimize any of this or 
project your personal disrespect for science upon the people who were 
created by this all powerful spirit. This is bigger than you can imagine. 
Others are trying to grasp it, how about you?

comments.text:
Sorry, you have it wrong at 0:12.

Reflection at a dielectric surface with greater refractive index results in 
polarized light regardless of input polarisation (could be random as with 
sunlight).

It does also depend on the angle, see Brewster's Angle.﻿
